alert.note: Alert for Chesterfield; Fairfield; Kershaw; Lee; Lexington; McCormick; Newberry; Northern Lancaster; Richland; Saluda; Southern Lancaster; Sumter (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Air Quality Alert issued July 18 at 9:48AM EDT by NWS Columbia
info.description: ... AIR QUALITY ALERT IN EFFECT FOR JULY 18TH ... Residents of South Carolina should be aware of the risk for health effects related to smoke from wildfires that originated from fires burning across parts of western Canada, the Department of Health and Environmental Control (DHEC) reported on Tuesday, July 18th. Smoke from these fires has been in place across the state since Monday, and smoke will likely continue through at least Tuesday, July 18th. Smoke can irritate the eyes and respiratory system, as well as aggravate or exacerbate chronic heart and lung diseases. An Air Quality Alert for fine particulates has been issued for the northern half of South Carolina, which will be in effect for July 18th. Counties within the Air Quality Alert include: Chesterfield, Fairfield, Kershaw, Lancaster, Lee, Lexington, McCormick, Newberry, Richland, Saluda, and Sumter. An Air Quality Alert means that the fine particulate concentrations within the affected region may approach or exceed unhealthy standards, especially for those individuals sensitive to particle pollution. It is expected that the health and visibility impacts from the smoke will continue within all regions of the state at least through the day Tuesday. The most significant smoke (and highest fine particulate concentrations) has been observed across northern South Carolina. As a result, unhealthy for sensitive individuals levels of fine particulate concentrations will be likely across the northern half of South Carolina through Tuesday. DHEC recommends individuals with respiratory health issues limit time spent outdoors to avoid the smoke. Keep windows and doors closed. Run an air conditioner if you have one but keep the fresh-air intake closed and the filter clean to prevent outdoor smoke from getting inside. For more information, please visit DHEC`s website at: http://www.scdhec.gov/HomeAndEnvironment/DisasterPreparedness/Wildfires/. For more information about the location of the wildfires, please visit: https://fire.airnow.gov
